review_title: Low Pay: jobs with no degree requirements earn more than STEM lab technician jobs
job_title: Lab Technician in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Beautiful Campus, can have flexibility depending on job/boss
cons: UofU continues to boast of gaining increased research funds while researchers get the same abysmal pay despite inflation. I was offered a salary less than living wage of SLC ($18.06 per MIT COL calculator) as a lab technician ($15-18.50/hour range in listing) which requires a STEM Bachelor's degree. Have now seen postings for "Parking enforcement officer", "Animal Care Technician", "Bus Driver" and "Medical Assistant" all $18+ with either sign-on bonuses or a raise within 6 months. These jobs do not require a bachelor's degree and are entry-level. STEM degrees are a lot of work and we are told as first-gen college graduates they open up career opportunities. The guidance counselors should check the job website, because it is just not true. Should have gone to industry for better pay, but I also want to go to grad school and was told my best chance is an academic university lab. Now regretting my decision and questioning if grad school is even worth it.

review_title: Good Culture and Benefits, But Low Pay
job_title: Senior Associate in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Benefits at the U are really great, good insurance, high retirement matching (around 14% if I recall), employees get 50% off tuition. Some jobs have a lot of flexibility regarding where and when you work. Most of the staff is very laid back and friendly. You get to interact with a lot of diverse and really smart people. You learn a lot while you are here, but you will always wonder if it is worth the pay cut.
cons: Pay is always going to be less than market rate, especially compared to private companies. The PTO time is somewhat generous, but I have found it hard to utilize due to workload. Projects can get wrapped up in office politics, especially at the higher levels, and because it is a public university everything takes ages to go through the approval process.

job_title: Student Grader in Salt Lake City, UT

cons: - Would sometimes get asked to grade other exams - Around my own exam season it would get busy - Sometimes difficult professors would expect you to come up with the answer sheet yourself

review_title: Many resources available but high burnout

job_title: Assistant Director in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The benefits were amazing for both retirement and medical insurance. There was a good amount of room to grow. I started entry level and worked up to an assistant director in my time there.
cons: The workload was very high and the management culture wasn't great. My office felt like a perpetual state of being understaffed and behind on work. Turnover for entry level processing jobs in my office was high. Compensation wasn't great and office budget was very limited. I also felt the schedule was unnecessarily strict.

review_title: Great place to work when looking at total comp
job_title: Senior Systems Administrator in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Lots of vacation and holidays (18 holidays, 4 weeks vacation, 10 days sick). Different vacation versus sick pay accrual pools. Two options for retirement savings. 401B at 14.2 % of your salary, as well as the ability to add money to other managed funds like IRA. Great insurance and other benefits Performance based raises Unlikely to be affected by economic ups and downs to a major degree
cons: Base pay is a little low. My section of the Org is fairly small without much more opportunity for advancement. Raises are performance based, but with a low cap (2% to 5% per year), and not much of an ability to negotiate pay raise without getting a new job. Very slow process to bring in new technical talent, and difficulty attracting top tier talent, and a tendency to keep bringing in project managers who are easy to hire, but often generate more meetings and questions rather than solutions

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Excellent benefits, work-life balance, and opportunities to improve your situation. Of course it really depends on where you work at the University. It is a massive employer and your experience can vary greatly depending on where you are. I've had OK experiences and above average experiences. Being a large employer you can find yourself in a dead-end job with a not so great manager. The good news is once you work at the U it gets easier to move to other jobs within the system. In my time at the U I've known lots of people who started in less desirable positions with lower pay completely change their situation by simply doing their job and taking opportunities to move as they come up. This review applies to staff. The faculty world is a different animal.
cons: Lower pay than typical for a given field. That said, I feel the benefits can compensate for the pay to a point. Being a massive employer you can find yourself in a dead-end job with a not so good manager.

cons: Some faculties really don't care about the student's career development and are just there to create a business from the available cheap labor. The university has zero control over who can become a faculty in what department. Overall, anything is possible as long as you know the right people. The scoring system for faculties is so loose and subjective that a sub-par postdoc can grow into a faculty with zero publication, pure air, and politics. review_title: Department that desperately needs an overhaul
job_title: Hazardous Waste Technician in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great work/life balance, lots of time off, relaxed and friendly work atmosphere, top-notch benefit package.
cons:
The hazardous waste side of the department (where I worked) is badly run down and years behind in terms of transportation, treatment and storage of hazardous waste.
The facility that I worked in was infested with insects and filthy-this includes the offices, not just the waste storage area. 
Because this is a transfer site for bio-waste, they routinely store animal parts and other infectious waste from the labs for multiple days, and have no way to refrigerate or freeze waste that is often beginning to rot before it even gets to the facility. The smell and bugs are at times disgusting.
Safety equipment was poorly maintained, with broken equipment not repaired or replaced, even after being brought to the attention of the management. 
We were required to transport hazardous chemicals through University buildings with no way to secure containers, including on elevators and through public areas where a spill could have resulted in serious hazard. When this was brought to the attention of the management, it was described as "standard operating procedure" and ignored.

Unfortunately, the University of Utah Office of Environmental Health and Safety lags far behind the private sector in some basic policies. There was no safety culture in place, or even a real understanding of what that means. Nepotism is common, while many positions seem to be redundant or occupied by people that no one ever sees. Training lags far behind for even the most basic hazmat requirements.
As with many older government departments, this one has become top heavy with retirement bound employees who seem quite happy as long as their boat isn't rocked. A situation that probably will not change, unfortunately, until there is a serious incident.

review_title: Exploits child care teachers and workers
job_title: Lead Child Care Teacher in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great U benefits (health insurance, PTO, paid holidays, tuition reimbursement). Thanks to being an employee of the University, probably would not exist if it were up to the Center for Child Care and Family Resources.
cons:
*Do not enroll your child at Ukids*
Management does not support its teachers at all. Ratios are illegal and they lie on their forms and licensing about how many children are actually in the classroom. When teachers are overwhelmed it's not their fault because their classrooms are understaffed and over-enrolled. This is a SERIOUS safety issue. They do not give their teachers adequate planning time or lunch breaks. When the pandemic first happened, they forced 40 teachers from 3 centers to report to one building to watch 10 children between the different centers. They cared more about making us work than keeping us safe and protected during the pandemic. When we asked why we couldn't split up and physically distance at different centers, we were told they didn't want to contaminate the buildings. We were expendable and disposable, and now they are paying the price with their inability to hire people. And the teachers that are still there suffer the most because they can't hire anyone. 

It's clear as a society how we value child care teachers but I expected a higher standard from the University. It is clear they just care about appearing good and lining their pockets at the top. Instead they exploit their teachers and lie to their parents about what is really happening at the child care center. Please do not blame teachers, they are either untrained or overworked.

review_title: Work is rewarding but pay abysmal
job_title: Senior Lecturer in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: There is a great deal that is rewarding about teaching at the U: the campus and research resources are terrific, students are generally engaged and interesting, and colleagues are friendly and supportive. The benefits (though they have become more expensive in recent years) are also good.
cons: Work-life balance is increasingly difficult to find--especially since the University has turned to an already overwhelmed faculty for more work during the pandemic. This is a particular challenge for contingent faculty who make up more than half of instructional staff at the U--but earn on average 30% less than tenure line. In recent years, the expectation for service work (usually on top of a pretty rigorous 3-3 teaching load) has increased. In some departments (like my own) there is also the strongly suggested desire to see research/scholarship from non-tenure faculty. And all of this has occurred while the cost of living in the area has skyrocketed (housing prices jumped +20% last year alone) and compensation has stagnated. Many in the Career Line ranks haven't seen a significant increase in pay in close to a decade--despite promotions in rank. All of this has taken a profound toll on morale, with many faculty choosing to leave or retire.

review_title: It all depends on the department you work for.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
One of the greatest reasons to work for the University of Utah is the accessibility to the scientific equipment. As a research assistant involved in various research projects in different areas, I need to use many, often expensive, instruments. Moreover, it is quite easy to gain access to various devices owned by different departments.
Second of all, University of Utah keeps a very close relationship with the industry. This results in many research projects which have a potential to be implemented in the real world. That also means a constant inflow of money that can be spend on new instruments and devices.
cons: The first important thing you have to remember, is that it all depends on the department you are working for. In my department very low salaries have to be the main downside. The second one will be the lack of experts in many areas that my department promises to conduct research in. That results in very high expectations put on lower lever researchers. Because of that there is no work/life balance. Respect for the senior researcher is very low. This department does not provide a lot of opportunities for personal development. And the only recognition for a good job you perform will be more pointless jobs in the future.

review_title: A good choice to graduate in Chemistry in the Department of Chemistry
job_title: Graduate Student-Physical Chemistry in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: It has a very good Graduate Program. It garantess you full financial support for 5 years. Usually enough to complete your PhD work. Salt Lake City itself is really cheap compared to other Cities with Top schools.  The Department itself has an excellent recognition for being good. The best thing about the Program is that some groups are top nationwide, that the school can easily compete with top schools like Berkeley or Purdue and such!  But the really cool thing about the program is the location: the best snow on earth during winter times and the best sceneries around summer time... more national parks than any other state in the US(except for Alaska).
cons: Really, no big ones...which would not be found in every other Chemistry Department Nationwide. The organic devision is regrowing right now, with fresh faculties. However the average graduation time was above 5 years, which was a little bit disturbing. However, it seems like that the organic and the biological devision nationwide takes longer anyways. So i dont think it is specific for this school. I dont know if this is a downside or not but the requirements for a PhD are a Seminar talk, then a Preoral and then a Proposal prior to defending your PhD thesis. But it can be good and bad...bad because some fail to pass these exams and have to leave with a Masters

review_title: Doesn't care much for graduate students
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Good facilities, great views from campus, most students are interesting people that are easy to get along with. Most professors are decent people to work with.
cons: Doesn't take care of engineering graduate students. Really bad health insurance, no vision, no dental insurance. If you get an outside fellowship in other departments (life sciences), you get them in addition to your salary. In engineering, they pull your salary if you get a fellowship. If you take more than 5 years to defend, which many do, you have to pay several thousand dollars to graduate. You also get charged $500-600 a semester in class "fees" even when just doing research, even though all tuition is supposed to be covered, as promised in contracts. I was given a surprise bill for $600 the first day of classes when I started. Most engineering departments here are extraordinarily cheap and always looking to cut corners at the expense of students. I'm honestly pretty disappointed that I chose to work on my PhD at Utah.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
Benefits are indeed excellent. They are trying to reduce carbon footprint by encouraging people to use public transportation. Reduction in parking and increased parking fees to reach this goal, mean that you will be doing A LOT of walking. On average, at least 15 minutes of walking from car to work.

I couldn't have survived without the support of support staff in similar positions. I have made professional friendships that will continue beyond my working at the U. I found support staff to be friendly and quite helpful.
cons:
Navigating the bureaucracy can be frustrating and intimidating. Depending on what department you are in, there may not be other support staff (to learn from). You must find counterparts of similar positions to reach out in time of need/direction. 

No real chance for promotion.

Pay for teaching is lower than other schools. Administrative pay seems to be about or slightly above average pay, but support staff are not paid appropriately for the amount of work they are required to do, I was expected to do the work of two full-time positions in 30 hours per week.

review_title: MS Candidate, Chemical Engineering. - Work-life balance depends on your advisor.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Many of the professors in the College of Engineering at the University of Utah have numerous contacts in industry.  My research here has opened doors to opportunities with many of them.  Free transit pass, easy to choose your own hours, and you get paid to do research.  Additionally, in the College of Engineering, you get a major discount on your tuition when your research is funded
cons:
Work-life balance is very dependent on your advisor for graduate school.  Mine is so hands off that it's a struggle to get his input on my research.  On one hand, I'm free to try out new ideas and approaches to problems.  On the other hand, a lack of structure makes it harder to prioritize work and set hard deadlines.  Other Professors will needle their students day and night for publications and  experimental results.

Additionally, while health benefits are excellent for a single student, the cost for getting University health insurance goes up tenfold when you try to add your spouse to a health plan.

job_title: Systems Administrator in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great environment to work in. Everybody here has "U" pride. People aren't too picky about how you dress, as long as its presentable. Vacation and time-off never was a hassle to get.
cons: Very bureaucratic. Sometimes the simplest of tasks can take months to get approval for. I.e. firewall changes. No centralized network infrastructure, you need to track down who is in charge of the individual building firewall/network and work with them to make changes, sometimes bringing in multiple people to move forward with a simple task that could've been done that day if there was a centralized network. My former boss would take advantage of me while I was working part-time, ordering me to stay long nights (20+ hour shift) doing server maintenance and other misc tasks. I worked 30+ hours a week while I was only a part-time, non-benefited employee. He did this for over a year promising a promotion and benefits to no avail. Fiscal budget reviews all the time constantly putting the job at risk.

review_title: A lot of perks but the cons are glaring
job_title: Associate Director in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
- Health insurance/benefits are outstanding
- Relatively casual office environment 
- State holidays
cons:
- Anything bigger than cost-of-living raises are non-existent; the U doesn't budget for merit raises except for faculty/administrative roles 
- On the salary note -- you could have a Master's degree and a manager title and still only receive $40,000. They consider this a competitive salary.
- Parking is awful and overpriced
- Not a lot of room for growth
- Staff often get overlooked -- two examples would be on bad weather days, they will cancel classes for faculty/students but inform staff to report to work, no matter how bad the roads are.   Another specific example is when the active shooter was loose on campus, they canceled classes for student safety but still made staff come to work even though the shooter could have been hiding in a building.

review_title: Great Benefits, but no room to advance.

cons:
There no off cycle pay raises. When raises are allowed they are highly scrutinized. at one point there were no raises allowed for years, not even cost of living. Tons of politics and upper management mishaps that lead to stress, going over budget and extra work that isn't needed. 

There is always construction and very old building that have things breaking all the time.

review_title: Employee and Student great work life balance
job_title: Executive Secretary in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Respectful of personal time (one can take a personal day if needed), protects employee vacation time, sick leave, very supportive of those on maternity and military leave.  I work on campus and also attend classes here so I don't have to fight traffic to get to school. The U cares about its employees and my bosses have all be very flexible with my school schedule and national guard commitments. I feel fully supported and very committed to this institution because of their support.
cons: It's a big campus with thousands of students attending year round so parking is a bit of a hassle, and traffic during peak times can be a pain as well. The school is actively building out more parking areas but there are simply too many people to keep up. I always find parking but I have to walk a little ways. Less than 10 minutes but more than 5.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: I can't think of any.
cons:
If I can give it a zero star, I totally would. All negatives and stereotypes about Utah were real when I stayed here. Of course I have long been told it is a very conservative and very religious place. But I DID not expect it to be this BAD. I mean OMG BAD~. Now all stereotypes have been proven to be true for Utahans. I am sure Mormons are very simple and very nice people. But the extreme white supremacists and racist is at another level. I mean unless you are a hardcore white conservative Mormon,  don't come to Utah. I respect their need for their own place and I will stay away. And I will leave them along. Students on campus are scared to death to even whisper any negative comments about Utahans, as peoples here are listening. If you dare to say anything negative, something bad will happen to you I am afraid. I am a fair-complexioned skin tone but OMG.

Another downside is the reason they will want you is to have you train their white Mormon technicians or students. They don't care about your career growth. You are just a tool for them and their development. Once  you were sucked out dry, you will be discarded like an used garment. So I really don't know what Pros are to come work here.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Spent 7 years as a postdoc there, it was a great learning experience. Friendly, and collaborative atmosphere. Very helpful management, administration and services. Active student and postdoc life. OK salary and good healthcare benefits.
cons: Outlook for advancing one´s career as a posrtdoc (to tenure) are bleak but not due to the institution, rather because of how the general system pits all those searching for a position and talking only to the top 2-4 candidates (out of 100-200). Take a field where there are 10-15 openings in a year across the US. All postdocs interested (100-200) apply for available positions, then the search committees picks 2-3-4-5 top candidates to give a presentation. All-in-all probably 8-15 of the original 100-200 gets to present across the US. Half of them are selected and offered a position.At least half of the open positions remain without a candidate. Postdocs cry about bleak outlook, department heads cry about how hard they have to compete with other institutions for the best postdocs. Solution: number of persons selected from the pool should be dependent on the overall number of open positions across the country (if filling up the post that year is important).

review_title: OK, as long as you have other options in SLC
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Good benefits, good facilities, on the edge of the Wasatch range, outdoor rec program equipment rental is the best thing ever. Discount ski lift tickets are a good value, lots of events on campus. I've met awesome people there, very few not awesome people.
cons: Pay could be better, gym isn't included, parking is cheap, but sometimes have to park half a mile from my building, dismal administrative support for postdocs. Public transportation to and from the U ends at 8:30 PM weekdays, earlier on weekends. Postdocs also have to pay for their own computers, this is not covered by the University. Food options are few on working days, slim on weekends. Some industries are growing around SLC, but at least the life sciences sector in SLC cannot absorb the talent coming out of the University.

job_title: Project Coordinator in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
The benefits are unbeatable.  The university contributes 14% of your salary to a retirement account.  That's money directly from the U, not taken from your salary.  You can then opt in to contribute from your actual salary.  Lots of health plan options.  Many insurance and retirement options.

In addition, if you do your job well, the U really tries hard to retain you.  My co-workers are all hard workers, but at the same time they don't overdo it.  My boss is very positive and appreciative of my work.  Overall it's a great environment.
cons: There isn't a lot of room for advancement (at least in my current office).  So I'm basically trading in a lower salary for amazing benefits and job security.

review_title: The hub of Utah academic activity
job_title: Associate Librarian in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The University provides a stimulating intellectual environment, with a strong connection to the regional and national academic community.  Pay in some categories seems lower than other Tier I universities, but it offers great benefits, including an off-the-top 14.2% contribution to retirement fund for faculty with no match required. There seems to be adequate funding to pursue research in many areas. Faculty and students are culturally more diverse than most Utah workplaces, and politically there is considerable variety. There is also considerable loyalty to existing staff and faculty.  The University is eager to compete nationally both academically and in its management. Ample good housing is available near the campus, and the city's public transportation system has improved recently, with a light-rail train serving the campus and downtown.
cons: State funding can be unreliable, with an antagonistic, conservative Legislature.  There is occasionally a tolerance of sloppy work that would not be tolerated at other Tier I universities.

review_title: Great job while getting an education, not longterm
job_title: Administrative Program Coordinator in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
Though it greatly varies by department, I feel like I am treated really well, like an actual human, with understanding upper management. 
There is a lot of freedom, I never feel micromanaged.
They have been very flexible and helpful with my education (also nice to receive 50% off tuition)- I wouldn't have been able to completely my bachelor degree if I didn't work for the U, frankly.
cons:
The pay is not great, and it's really hard to get a meaningful raise. Our annual raises don't even match inflation.
There is little room to grow. Management level opportunities are very few and far between. Many coordinators I know have been doing the same thing for years with no hope of progression.

job_title: Doctor in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Nice people.  Feel valued.  Growing (a good sign in healthcare).  Invest in employees (promotion, further degrees, able to move within departments--caveat: talking about health care).  Good benefit.  Smart leaders (you want this, trust me re: strategy, marketing, operations, and vision!).
cons: Salary is definitely worse than other states.  This is mainly due to Utah (high demand to live, more supply than demand given LDS pull--though not have to be LDS to succeed or have good relationships).  Definitely a culture shock for people from the East (where I came from).  Play nice/team player.  Don't gossip.  Yet do not be naive (passive aggressive interactions in past with some locals in contrast to east coast "direct feedback" approach).  High cost of living re: housing if want to live close.  Parking is horrible.

review_title: Great for Full-Time, Awful for Part-Time Employees (ie moms)
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Good reputation, many specialties, forefront of research
cons:
The commute is awful, whether it's foothill drive or the freeway. I spent 1 1/2 hours driving and I only live seven miles away from work. You have to spend hundreds of dollars a year on parking and I still drive around for 45 minutes trying to find a spot. 
If you are part-time, they look down on you. They only give you two hours a month of PTO and unpaid time off is not allowed so you literally can never take a vacation. That is three days a year!

review_title: An interesting experience; would not recommend
job_title: in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Situated in a well kept city in a beautiful natural setting.  Slow pace.  Very good for families.  Cost of living smaller than in other parts of the country.
cons: The people!  Most of them are insecure and under trained and very willing to keep things the way they are.  They can get defensive and resistant to any change even if that is in their own best interest.  Lack of a real community.  Very insular and provincial and with no intention to change that.

review_title: Graduate Engineering Student - Stay for the outdoors.  Leave for better resources.
job_title: Graduate Student Engineering in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: I've loved living in Salt Lake.  Surprisingly great live music and restaurants for the size of the city.  Many great coffee shops for studying.  Counseling center is cheap and accessible.
cons: Difficult to find a supportive network to teach me how to navigate the combined female/engineer/graduate student roles.  There are classes and resources, but many I didn't know even existed until later in my graduate student life.  Many I discovered on posters posted in the library.  Professors were tight-lipped and too PC when real, genuine advice was desperately needed about how to overcome obstacles.  I felt dropped on my head.  It's taught me to fight, but it's not my preferred method of learning.  It's a university right?

job_title: Full Stack Developer

The 14.2% retirement benefit is nice.  Healthcare is reasonable and provides many choices.  Management is rather "stodgy" and stuck in old ways, but getting far better in the last few years.   Do not expect to use the greatest personal tools as budgets are very limited.  Cleverness is an appreciated asset.
cons:
Limited budgets
Some horrible teams and some great teams.
Very unreliable levels of competence and methodology from team to team across the company.

UIT

review_title: Perfect job to  do while at the U

With the great benefits like the stellar health insurance, tuition discount, and 401(a) retirement contribution (about 14% of your salary is contributed to a 401(a) account at no cost to the employee) My actual compensation most years is between 50%-75% higher than my base salary, which I really appreciate.
cons: Both policy and culture tend to treat "Staff" like second class citizens compared to "Faculty" regardless of whether the staff member is a janitor or highly trained professional. Limited opportunity for advancement. Pay is significantly lower than the industry standards for my profession, but the benefits do off set this. Often times the bureaucratic processes of the university cause a huge obstacle to getting things done.

job_title: Chemistry Teaching Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT

cons: Do not put a large amount of emotional time and energy into the position as your effort will fall flat on its face.  Students may praise you, but even with positive class evaluations do not expect any recognition or acknowledgement from the institution, most teachers and TAs are putting in minimum effort so do the same, get in get out ... thats the attitude after teaching many classes, I am an undergraduate and had to hold graduate students hands in my neighboring classrooms going so far as taking my time to explain things to their students who were always confused.  Many incompetent graduate students here

review_title: Campus Shuttles, Division of Commuter Services

cons: I'm being forced to write something in the con section for this to be submitted.  So hopefully I can reach the 20 word minimum.  The fact that I don't get a tuition break is pretty dumb (I'm an undergrad).  It's not like I can work 40 hours AND expect to succeed in my degree (mathematics--very time consuming).

job_title: Customer Service Associate in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great flexibility with student part-time schedules.  Big benefit:  free textbook loan/rental program.  Opportunities to advance to supervision positions if you're a good work.  I started as a customer service associate as a temp for semester opening but had opportunities to advance internally later on.  They were also starting a cross departmental leadership training program by the time I left.  A self-described "gnarly" culture, a great place to make  friends (esp. for a commuter student like me).
cons: It's retail, so everything that comes with that. Textbook theft was becoming a problem when I left, I wish I would have had better anti-shoplifting training before being asked to do security work.  Sometimes balance with school schedule could be compromised--some work on Saturdays for football games.

job_title: Marriott Library Staff in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The University of Utah was a good place to work. I worked there for a few years while earning my degree. Co-workers were nice and friendly, pay was good for a student job. Management was reasonable and friendly. Job was rarely stressful. Benefits for full time positions are great. Despite the few cons and advice to management, this is my favorite job. I left to gain more experience and earn a higher salary, but the U, in particular the Marriott Library was a great place to work.
cons: Quite a bit of bureaucracy and politics goes on. Some tenured employees are self-aggrandizing. Some staff take their sweet jobs for granted and are lazy.

review_title: Great environment & work culture.  Weak leadership.  Great benefits, low pay.
job_title: IT Analyst in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: University environment is free thinking.  The campus is beautiful. Work culture is friendly and respectful.  They provide very good benefits including free public transportation.  The retirement package is the best ever.  Training and employee development are excellent.
cons: The campus is divided up into many kingdoms where administrators battle for power and control.  Teams and divisions are divided even within departments where much infighting occurs as administrators battle for power and control.  Morale can be low.  Pay is below market for similar jobs.  Decisions are made by committee, including hiring. Lack of career path.

review_title: Good Benefits, A Lot of Bureaucracy
job_title: Administrative in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The pay is decent relative to Salt Lake City averages, and the benefits are generally good.  Health is good, dental is OK, psychological is acceptable, and vision coverage is poor.  The staff work culture is very sedate, great place to work if you want to take it easy.
cons: Career advancement is difficult without moving between departments.  Salary increases are dependent on the Utah State Legislature (translation: don't expect more than 1-2%).  The application/interview/hiring process is extensive for almost any position, it's best to apply if you already have a job elsewhere and can spare the time.

review_title: Ask as many questions as possible before joining a lab
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: For my field, one of the best departments in the nation. very entrepreneurial spirit with the Lassonde Center which pairs science/engineering graduate students with MBAs. great location to trails for running or mt biking.
cons: because it is a commuter campus there doesn't seem to be much community or intellectual gatherings. I wasn't impressed with the career service. As with any graduate program, ask as many questions as possible before joining a group. departments will not necessarily look out for you so you need to stick up for yourself, even if it means standing up to your advisor.

review_title: All is not as it appears
job_title: Medical Billing Account Specialist in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Benefits are unmatched,  they're amazing. The atmosphere is good and coworkers are good.  Close to no office drama.  Good yearly bonus.
cons: Micromanagement is really bad.  The managers don't listen or seem to care Abbott the employees under them.  Supervisors are held under a microscope and given far too many responsibilities and a ton of stress which they can tend to take out on their employees. They pay a flat rate to employees based on title.  People working 1 day and people that have been there 15 years make the same amount.

review_title: An OK place to work, if you're still studying
job_title: Research Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Well, as a student, it's a good job in the labs. Better than delivering pizza, but it's still a student job. The people are generally really good to work with, though. I don't have a whole lot to do most of the time, which I guess can be a good thing, but it's also really boring because of that.
cons: Poor coordination between departments, and in general there is a lot of moving around between buildings, at least in the engineering areas. You're underpaid because you work for the state, officially, but you can get your work submitted for part of an advanced degree, which I'm not doing cuz I don't care.

review_title: hahI am getting back to my normal academic routine, I realize that my current college studies are not enough to fulfill
job_title: Research Associate in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: I am getting back to my normal academic routine, I realize that my current college studies are not enough to fulfill my career aspirations. With a strong interest in quantitative analysis and my interdisciplinary background, I would love to work as a quantitative analyst in the financial field and contribute to technological innovations such as high-frequency trading.
cons: I am getting back to my normal academic routine, I realize that my current college studies are not enough to fulfill my career aspirations. With a strong interest in quantitative analysis and my interdisciplinary background, I would love to work as a quantitative analyst in the financial field and contribute to technological innovations such as high-frequency trading.

review_title: EAE: Top Ranked Program for Good Reason
job_title: Adjunct Professor in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
Positivity. Program Director (Dr. Kessler) cares about the students and is an industry visionary. His influence is an outstanding positive. 
Adaptive. Program is mindful of crafting an experience that provides maximum impact and value to the students and evolves to meet recognized needs.
Inspiring. The student body inspires through focus on craft, collaboration and teamwork.
Progressive: 1st in Nation with competitive scholarship program in gaming.
Results. The students are coming out of the program, primed for positive impact.
cons:
Politics. I have been spared the politics, but they are regrettably, a part of any and every scholastic institution.
Parking. Good luck with that. UTA TRAX really helps with congestion, but if you're driving, finding a spot to park is always a tenuous proposition.

job_title: Academic Advisor in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Good healthcare coverage (inc dental and decent mental health referrals), opportunity for valuable professional relationships, conveniently located, free transportation
cons: Staff (at least in the departments I have worked in: Admissions and Public Health), do not get bonuses, annual raises, merit-based raises, etc. There are little to no incentives for going above and beyond, though most do regardless. Research faculty and funding is prioritized, while staff wellness and growth is not.

job_title: Assistant Accounting Manager in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Good working environment, benefits, co-workers.  It really is a wonderful place to work.  Don't let the cons listed below turn you off.
cons: Large company politics.  Instead of managing, you get excuses like "if we work with your scheduling needs we would have to work with everyone's"

review_title: Good benefits, generally positive environment, getting a bit top heavy
job_title: Research Associate Professor in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
The provided benefits (especially health care) are very good and resonably priced.
All employees are given free passes for transit which, if you live in the right area, is perfectly adequate for getting to/from work.
People are generally respectful of work/life balance.
cons:
The salaries can be a bit low relative to the cost of housing in SLC.
All construction, everywhere, all the time.
Dependent on Utah State Legislature for funding.
Explosion of administrative positions at expense of education.
Revenues increasingly a focus.

job_title: IT Team Lead in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Very beautiful campus at the foothill of Wasatch Front; Many interesting events to attend such as seminars, presentations, and discussions; access to many services such as career center; libraries, gyms; opportunities for education; flexible schedule; intellectually stimulating;
cons: It is a wonderful place to be as a student employee, but the pay is very low. You don't have much upward mobility; things move very slowly because of bureaucracy; parking on campus is a big problem.

job_title: Field Services in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The benefits. Free tuition. Easy access to trax and other forms of transportation. Incredible medical benefits. It's also very stable work. They don't fire people even when they are obvious dirt bags among the ranks. So if you're looking for a place to work where you aren't held to really high standards. I guess this would probably be in the downsides section
cons: The pay is not as good when compared to others doing this same line of work in the private sector. Just like I was saying earlier. Some people look towards government jobs as a place to receive a decent paycheck for not doing very much work.

job_title: Executive Secretary in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Co-workers often come from diverse cultural backgrounds. Promotions often come from within. Good benefits. Tuition discount. Lots of opportunities to advance - you can keep an eye on the University job site for current employees if your current department isn't promoting.
cons: I've worked in 5 different departments at the U of U, but at only 2 of those jobs did I feel that I was fairly compensated for the level of worked required.

job_title: Administrative in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Half tuition, decent health plan, beautiful campus
cons:
There is NO room for growth. Stayed in same position for 8 years and never had an opportunity to advance and barely made enough money to live. "Management", however, makes well over six figures and constantly denies raises for us little people. 

Extremely political and unprofessional environment. Once spent 10 minutes in staff meeting discussing black lives matter and how evil cops are, and was strongly pressured to hang signs on my office door saying I supported undocumented students. But paid maternity leave? Out of the question.

review_title: Just as you'd imagine a library job: it's easy but with low pay.
job_title: Collections Services Coordinator in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: It's a government library job, so it's fairly stress-free and cushy. Given the unimportance of library work, you're pretty much free to take vacation or call in "sick" whenever you need.
cons: Unless you want to work at a library the rest of your life, it will do nothing for you with respect to legitimate professional experience (unless you're a top-level administrator). Work satisfaction is low and so is the wage. It's frustrating to see the inefficiencies that are maintained because management as no incentive to correct them.

review_title: Learned loads, got paid little, but what can you expect as an undergrad?
job_title: Undergraduate Researcher in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Massive amounts of learning and people willing to help you the whole way through your time there. Incredible cutting edge visualization and computational programs. Uintah, SCIrun, and many others blew my mind. Some of the smartest and brightest computer programmers and computational analysts work here. I was very impressed.
cons: Must be good at personal time management as most projects are self-directed. I enjoyed the freedom but it got difficult at times to stay on task. If you are very self-motivated you would do fine, if not it just takes a minute to get used to.

job_title: Computer Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Love campus atmosphere and closeness to food and shopping options
cons: Too many layers of management (someone was a head of a department of one, herself); negative attitude from the top down; upper management not transparent; there was someone so incompetent as an accountant we nearly got audited and she still wasn't let go until eight months after she proved she was not proficient or even competent at her job

review_title: The U never seems to get there as far as taking care of staff
job_title: in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Stable place to work with a decent benefits package.  Close proximity to many different outdoor recreation opportunities.  World class health care with new and expanding specialties and facilities.
cons: Opportunities for growth and development are limited.  Reliance on state funding and adherence to keeping the status quo limit career options and make it difficult to advance both professionally and financially.  Staff leadership at both the University and hospital are stagnate.

review_title: Best University I have ever been to, and best culture and professionalism
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
- Lots of RA and TA opportunities
- Lots of respect to students as if they were colleagues to professors
- Top notch research projects
- Best of class environment: all grad students with research interests are offered an office in - school (no not cubical, a real office).
- True involvement in leading research projects
cons:
- Difficult to get a full-time professor job (as is the case in all universities)
- University Housing is not that good for such a prestigious university (It should show better standards).

job_title: Program Coordinator in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: I have a very difficult time saying anything positive about my time working at the University of Utah.
cons: The worst job I have ever had. They cannot retain employees so can only focus on training new employees who then leave as fast as they possibly can. The school is in bad condition, the offices are terrible. Horrible management. The only reason they get away with operating the way they do is because they the largest college in the Salt Lake Valley. I would never recommend the University of Utah as an employer. I was actually told, "expect to be overworked and underpaid" by my supervisor. Zero culture. The excuse that everyone uses is that it is a decentralized campus. That's not the issue.

review_title: The absolute worst place I have ever worked.
job_title: Data Analyst in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Generous benefits on the taxpayer's dime.
cons:
First day of the job I was told by a co-worker to put my head down, don't make any suggestions, and only ever do exactly as I'm told.
Cannot ask questions without gaining a reputation for not knowing what you're doing.
Religious bigotry is RAMPANT in this organization.  They're trying to keep one very specific faith out.
HR is useless.
You have nothing to do for 8 solid hours, but you can't leave your desk.  Then, at 9 PM, they call you to perform some work that could have been done earlier.
When you comment on an inefficiency, they just shrug and say "that's how we've always done it."
Employees will abuse the databases by looking up your salary information and management doesn't care.
Absolutely useless meetings.

review_title: Great experience with the Writing Center
job_title: Writing Consultant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Flexible hours, decent pay, great co-workers. I think this is a great job for full-time students who have the patience to deal with English Second Language learners and students who really struggle with academic writing.
cons: Mis-scheduling was often an issue, the pressure became quite intense during finals. There were sometimes issues where students wanted grammar correcting machines, instead of writing tutors, and dealing with them could be frustrating. But that's just the nature of working with undergraduate students.

job_title: Classroom Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The director of the center is phenomenal and a pleasure to work with. Caring and close-knit staff. Developed great relationships with the kids. Flexible hours for college students. Supportive work environment. I loved coming to work everyday and didn't mind staying later to help in the classroom or cover for others. NAEYC accredited child-care center.
cons: Low-pay. Some of the rules and protocols, such as how far apart the nap mats should be from each other and charting their bathroom activity, can seem nit-picky (but they are necessary for licensing and you do get used to them). Some children were difficult to work with but that's always to be expected at a childcare center.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Easy to obtain the position as they are always willing to have more ambassadors to help motivate students to come to U of U. The job has helped me to speak better in front of people and audiences, as well as better learn how to teach others. Especially exciting to help motivate and excite other students (such as high school students) about the degree/program which you are also passionate about.
cons: The work is very simple, and therefore the pay is not great. ($10/hr) Also, the times to help/work are always different and many times only equates to ~10 hours a month of work, but this may be good for students with heavy school workloads.

review_title: Good working environment, nice people, nice city, glad i'm here.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
People in Utah are very kind and nice, good neighbor, good environment for graduate student. The income though not too high the cost of living is really low make this a competitive place to live. 
If you like skiing and hiking, this is one of the best place to do that. It has good reputation for certain fields not for everyone
cons: It is not very competitive. It is not the top school. Life is little boring if you like city life

review_title: Great place to work; sometimes a little bureaucratic
job_title: Teaching Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The pay is fair and they provide good, flexible hours most of the time. The facilities are nice, usually clean and professional. Great coworkers and general environment, although sometimes there is a lot of red tape.
cons: Seniority rules, so if you end up underneath someone who is incompetent, lazy, or just doesn't like you then you're in for a rough ride. Change is slow, and suggestions are rarely taken as seriously as they ought to be.

job_title: Bio Statistician in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Overall, I was satisfied with the benefits (with the exception of how long it took to get COBRA coverage). More importantly, I worked with exceptional and competent people.
cons: I wasn't allowed to work remotely, which was a huge disadvantage for me because I had a two hour commute (one way) on public transportation every day. I also was disappointed by how long it took to get COBRA coverage after my employment ended, which was especially frustrating because I was pregnant and needed health insurance.

review_title: It all depends on which department you work for.
job_title: Accounting Specialist in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great benefits and flexible schedules (provided your department allows this - most do).  Understanding of work/life balance.  Great Vacation and Sick.  The pay is OK, but you have to negotiate well when you take the job since "raises" are only inflation adjustments - therefore you never make more unless you move positions.
cons: It all depends on the department but there is a high concentration of unqualified managers with no people skills.  It seems most have been rewarded with a managerial position because they were there long enough - not because they had the skills.

review_title: A review of University of Utah IT.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: I worked with U of U IT for over 4 years and it was a great place to work most of those years. The division has a lot of great people working with and for them.
cons: A few key leaders are fostering a hostile, punitive and confusing environment within University IT and its interfacing departments. The once collaborative environment has become mandate-driven and dissent is stifled instead of respected. The infighting is very strong and damaging. The current environment has caused the University to lose or disenfranchised many talented and deeply respected professionals. It is not a good time to be working with or for University IT.

review_title: Excellent place to work as a high school student during the summer. There are many research opportunities.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
-The hourly wage is great for a summer job as a high school student or college student. 
-The atmosphere in most research labs is rather laid back
-You will have the opportunity to learn many new things (as long as you ask questions and are interested in your work)
-Research experience looks great on your resume
cons:
-For many high school students, the jobs can be rather monotonous. However, it varies from group to group
-At times you may not have a lot of direction regarding what you should do. Although, this gives the chance to a self-directed learner

review_title: Minimum Pay Defined by Department But Not Enforced
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Go for the master's degree. Skip the PhD. Get a job. Start building your 401K.
cons: Minimum pay was defined by the departments but not enforced. There was great discrepancies in pay purely based on the group you were doing research in. Our group was a mix of engineers and scientist. They wanted us to all have the same starting pay even though engineers had to pay differential tuition and the physicts did not. So engineers lost about 1/3 of their salary right off the bat.

review_title: Worked for the Lassonde Entrepreneur  Institute, loved it.
job_title: Marketing Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
First off this is specific to Lassonde, I can't speak for other departments
-flexible work schedule
-my boss was great, really wanted the best for students, he would always share any opportunities to get involved with great programs
-I got to work from my dorm a lot of the time
-they tried to find the best ways to maximize my skills in my work
cons: -literally the most objectionable part of this job was walking across campus for weekly meetings with my boss, honestly, it was a great job overall and I'd recommend it to anyone

review_title: PhD Candidate in Chemical Engineering- great environment that fosters education and experience.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: While the hours are long and you have to work well past 40 hour weeks you get a great education, and there's still some time to have fun and take in all that Salt Lake City has to offer, including all the ski resorts and hiking trails within half an hour of campus.
cons: You will end up working more than 40 hours a week.  Sometimes it feels like you'll never finished.  No validation for the work you're doing until you get the degree in the end.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The University of Utah has been growing rapidly over the past decade. As a consequence of increased budget for research, more opportunities, with satisfying paychecks, are created. People here are very friendly and believe in the style of providing freedom for research. Collaboration with universities and research labs in the west coast adds value, in terms of knowledge sharing, to the work routine.
cons: University of Utah is still not recognized to the extent of Universities such as University of Michigan Ann Arbor, UT Austin etc.

job_title: Finance Teacher Assistant/Tutor in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
- Great opportunity for somebody looking for recommendations 
- Makes you appreciate all your teacher needs to do for the students
- Great opportunity to gain experience with administrative work
cons:
- Boring! 
- Bad pay for this specific position. Unless you have several students coming in for tutoring and you are spending a great amount of time with them, you don't get much out of this in terms of pay

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: A lot of flexibility in performing research is available to graduate students. The professors are great mentors and extremely helpful. All the necessary tools to conduct research are available.
cons: Sometimes it is stressful to meet deadlines on projects but I guess it would be like any other job. Although you don't have to work on weekends but as a student sometimes you might want to dedicate as much time as you can on your research.

review_title: Great Place to Work with Fantastic Benefits!
job_title: Administrative Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The healthcare and retirement savings plans are both excellent. The culture can also be really great, depending on which department you're a part of. Also, once you're a part of the U community, there are many opportunities for lateral or upward mobility - but beware that Masters Degrees are abundant.
cons: Raises are far and few between - each year all employees receive a 1%-3% raise depending on the legislature, and any raises above this amount are difficult to come by. This system can often mean that simply by working for an extended period of time you will make more, but your efforts are rarely rewarded.

job_title: Senior Business Systems Analyst in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Benefits and Tuition reductions that's it.
cons: Beware of certain areas at the U as silos exist. MBA's Phd's arrogance, particularly more with insecure men with whole egos. If your not their puppet they will cast you out as different and undeserving. In the grand scheme of things what perfect place than to work than a public institution these insecure narcissistic men. The people who know deep down inside they will never make out there in the real world are the ones who unfortunately are employed here. Ask the tougher questions to the direct leader you would be working for.  In the medical area people who change the world and know they are and let it get to there head. Its academics for ya.

job_title: Research Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: I had a blast while I was working as a research assistant for Professors Ganesh Gopalakrishnan and Matt Might. The research was also very engaging, and I learned a lot from these two.
cons: I would say that the only cons that really come to mind while I was working at the University of Utah was the lack of clear organization. However, that encouraged me to ask a lot of questions, and in the process, I learned a lot, so it wasn't a negative experience at all.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The U has a dynamic and collaborative scientific community, and plenty of resource cores for easy access to more expensive or challenging research tools. The university is research focused in the sciences, so I think most professors have a good trade-off of research and teaching duties.
cons: The salary is quickly becoming insufficient (or already is) for most graduate students. The health insurance is skeletal and pretty much unmanageable for anyone who makes as little as we do.

job_title: Instructor in Philadelphia, PA
pros: As a graduate instructor, I can't say much about what it's like to work as a salaried professional at the U, but from those I interacted with, it's a great place to work.  The hours are generally flexible, the location is excellent, and access to university facilities adds considerable value.
cons: As a state-run institution in a highly conservative state where the state government considers the U too liberal, expect funding challenges and the accompanying stresses.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Grad school was awesome. Learned from dozens of PIs with a wide variety of expertise. All were friendly with an open door policy. Led to great opportunities for employment post graduation.
cons: Some departmental politics were off-putting but could be avoided by focusing on working with people in your research area. Grad student and post-doc pay is low but that's true anywhere in the U.S.

review_title: as expected from a postdoc position
job_title: Postdoctoral Researcher in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
- Independence
- Enough funding from professors
- Great place to live if you are outdoorsy (hiking, camping, skiing, kayaking, etc)
cons:
- Not a career (expected to move out in a few years)
- Low salary when compared to other engineering jobs in the industry
- No retirement plans
(All these are expected from a postdoc position)
-Not in the top 10 universities, so finding a tenure-track faculty job is almost impossible.

review_title: Great place to work, but don't get stagnant
job_title: IT Manager in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
I worked in three different departments at "The U" in an IT capacity--one in the School of Medicine and two in other non-academic departments. If you enjoy working around students and faculty, then it's a fantastic place to build/make a career! I especially enjoyed being part of a larger community and not just a member of my department.

Benefits are great--medical, PTO, etc. There is no 401(k) match--they instead contribute to a 403(b) in the amount of 14.2% of your salary. While salaries are lower than those in the private sector, the 403(b) contribution is pretty amazing and makes up for some of that gap.

Half-price tuition is a huge benefit, too. I wouldn't have been able to do my Master's program without it.

Campus life during football season is also especially fun! #goutes
cons:
The recession of the early 2000s was rough--we went 2-3 years without a compensation increase. When raises returned, they were still only 1-2%. Factor that in with lower than private sector pay and that doesn't equate to much of a salary increase. Think hundreds instead of thousands. Raises may depend a bit on department (I believe the Medical Center definitely pays more), but that was my experience.

Depending on which department you work in, career progression can be a mixed bag. If you work in UIT, there are many roles that you can progress through. If you are a one-man IT shop in another department, though, those opportunities are a lot more sparse. When I was there, there was no clear way to move from one department to another--they each acted as their own silo. While there is a campus IT community, don't assume your manager will be able to help you with career progression--assuming you are in an IT role outside of UIT.

Because of this lack of progression, it can be easy to become stagnant in your role/career progression. This isn't just in IT, either--I know others that fill a unique role within the University where there isn't a lot of upwards movement available.

review_title: Mediocre salary and no raises but great benefits
job_title: in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Pension and tuition benefits; pride in working for a state supported higher ed school
cons: Low salary and no pay increases in several years.

review_title: Delightful experience as a part time staff
job_title: Office Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Extremely good group of people that have similar interests in advancing higher education. The workload was reasonable and as student, each department understands that school work always take priority over your duties.
cons: Pay was not as favorable for lower level staff, but hey it's a resume builder and you get plenty of good experience by just interacting with people around you.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Work for one of the best universities in the state. Jobs open at the University every day, so there are plenty of opportunities to move up within the school.
cons: Pretty large bureaucracy. Traffic getting to the school each day is a total nightmare. Working with students can be hard; this is their life, so they are often understandably irate when something goes wrong.

review_title: Wonderful working for the U, high stress job and difficult people.
job_title: Graduate Academic Support Specialist/Residency Evaluator in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Half off tuition after 6 months, amazing co-workers, can take HR classes, the benefits are wonderful including dental insurance and access to red med.
cons: Working with angry customers a lot who will verbally abuse you. It’s high stress around busy season and not uncommon to cry at work.

review_title: Ineffective Leadership with no accountability-- No one challenges they just follow, bystanders
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Positive purpose in serving the students
cons:
Terrible pay
Director unaccountable
Culture of unaccountability 
POC treated differently or if you don't fit, you will be treated differently.
Ineffective management (Director)

review_title: If you don't like being treated fairly, this is the place for you.
job_title: Bookstore Specialist in West Jordan, UT
pros: The work environment is awesome. The employee discount is awesome.
cons: Upper level management, Terrible retention rate. Unnecessary drama by upper level management. Randomly being laid off, and having to figure out for yourself why you are being laid off.

review_title: Nice school at a nice location
job_title: Research Associate in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
The university is in salt lake city, where you can do lots of outdoor activities, biking,hiking,fishing,hunting,camping,skiing etc, if you are an outdoor guy/gal.

I also love the campus and the atmosphere in my workplace. The campus bike/walk/skateboard friendly and you can get around with free campus shuttles. The staff and colleagues at the department I worked are nice and friendly.
cons: The traffic to the school is sometimes miserable because the campus is located against the mountain and there are basically only two roads leading the campus.

review_title: Nice enough place to work, little oversight of upper management
job_title: Study Coordinator in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Nice facilities, great health insurance. Easy to access via public transit.
cons:
Terrible parking situation---constantly taking away expensive permit parking ($300/yr) to put up pay parking garages that have even more expensive permits ($700/yr). 
Lots and lots of nepotism. One of my supervisors told me to do something illegal and when I reported it nothing happened because this person was the spouse of someone in charge. Someone in my position before me reported the same supervisor and was  blackballed from other positions with different faculty within the same department.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Get real world experience in the area you’re studying, hours are usually flexible, opportunities to network and find employment for after graduation, full tuition benefit
cons: Although when you work the hours is flexible, the number of hours worked is ridged. As a GRA, there is no sick time or vacation time, you have to work an average of 20 hours a week for the semester. If you fail to do so, you have to pay back the tuition benefit. But, managers are usually flexible about when the hours you miss can be made up.

review_title: UofU- amazing benefits and okay experience.
job_title: Project Manager in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Diverse community, 14% vested at hire, benefits are comprehensive and affordable, and training opportunities available.
cons: Politics in departments is real. Support is given to those favored and there is a lot of back biting. In 14 years of experience at the UofU, unless it was in a graduate program, I did not witness a lot of supervisors trying to lift employees to a career. It was a lot of, "I made it here from stepping on the backs of others. I will NOT help someone get to where I am without doing the same"

review_title: Very political; its who you know, not what you know
job_title: Data Entry Specialist in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Worked with very nice people and there were other nice people higher up in the management, just terrible in the department I worked in.
cons: Very unprofessional and immature management. I was very disappointed and expected much more from the University of Utah. This job changed my view of the University because I was disgusted with the management and what they get away with.

review_title: The atmosphere is good with good support staff.  The building and facilities are a bit on the old side but adequate.
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: 3 weeks vacation is good and the medical coverage is good.  The location is great for outdoor activities.  There are very student oriented here.  The core facilities are good and not too expensive.
cons: There are no retirement options for post doctoral fellows.  The building is old and the facilities can be scare.  Getting things fixed take more time than I feel is necessary and construction has been constant since I arrived.

job_title: Tutor in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
The compensation is great, especially for students.
Benefits offered.
Compensation Process well developed, and not hidden from employees
Communication with supervisors good
cons: I felt like I could have received more training. I don't think I was fully competent until my second month of work, but there are always people willing to give you honest feedback.

job_title: Computer Sales Specialist in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: It was a great place to work as a full-time student because I was able to work plenty of hours and attend class, quite stress free. My co-workers were wonderful as well and the managers are very helpful. I really enjoyed meeting so many people on campus, from students to faculty. My opinion there was also accepted and therefore I felt very valuable to the team.
cons: Sometimes you can't get all the hours you want and the supervisor training classes typically clash with a heavy school schedule.

job_title: IT Specialist in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Stability and benefits are probably the best things about working for the University. Since things at the U do not move quickly there is always time to catch your breath.
cons: The U has a bureaucracy problem as does any government organization however, the U's is worse since the office of the President really has no functional control over the other departments they can all act as independent colleges without the university rules.

review_title: Nice Working Environment, with good opportunity to grow
job_title: Software Design Engineer in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
-- You will not get micromanaged here.
-- New ideas are always welcome.
-- If you come up with new ideas, then you are most likely going to lead those ideas and carry those forward.
-- Not extremely fast paced
-- Data Scientists have good prospect, due to the NEMSIS data that is collected for research.
-- Operating under the supervision of University of Utah, School of Medicine, the employees are eligible for all the University Campus Employee benefits.
cons: -- Clear communication between the client requirements and the developers needs to be improved.

job_title: in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Upcoming university so lots of funding and opportunities. Relatively small university with less student to teacher ratio.
cons: No maternity policies for graduate students and you are at the mercy of your advisor. There is no one to go to without being afraid of being fired, if you have disagreement with your advisor.

review_title: Postdoctoral Fellow at University of Utah
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The University of Utah is a great research environment. It is Highly collaborative between departments and provides a strong opportunity to associate with highly skilled and talented researchers.
cons: Like most universities, postdocs at the University of Utah are subject to academic politics and often low pay. There is no consistent policy for postdoc pay and benefits and no clear program for advancement and pay increases.

job_title: College Access Advisor in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Flexible schedule with great opportunities to work with a diverse array of people. It is also nice to work in such an innovative environment where people are genuinely open to new ideas.
cons: There is not much benefits for part time workers even if they are students which make it difficult to work and pay for the ever increasing tuition bills that the university imposes

job_title: Research Study Coordinator in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great benefits, lots of opportunities to grow with the company as a whole, top tier research institution
cons: Equal opportunity policies are not enforced, employees are strongly discouraged from taking any sort of protected leave, pay is typically less than other companies, no type employee advocate exists, most larger research groups with the U focus on money as opposed to the patient, little work/life balance exists, study coordinators are required to be avail 24/7 (including during vacation/PTO)

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
Overall, open-minded, ethical culture.
Excellent benefits that make up for the usual lower salaries
cons: I came from the business world, and there is still too much of a gulf between the two environments, except in the professional programs and engineering.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The place is very safe, welcoming, and friendly. The labs are well equipped for research, and the professors are very helpful.
cons: Some of the departments are very good. It is not easy to take classes from the other department or to pursue a minor. The lab during the winter is freezing, so it would be great if that can be fixed.

review_title: Good job security, no raises or advancement
job_title: Lab Technician in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The benefits of working at the U of U is the benefit package, along with the job security. That and the free commute on Trax.
cons: I have worked at the U for about 4 years. Despite having excellent reviews from all of my bosses, I have not received a single raise.

job_title: Police Dispatcher
pros: Graveyard shift you can study and its quiet and less political most nights.  The department is made up of people who live from paycheck to paycheck or use the University benefits for tuition reduction.
cons: No loyalty, the equipment is so cheap because the department will not spend money on modern technology and it shows amongst the users, the administration is predominantly from West Valley who were involved in fraudulent activity and quit abruptly to save face.  Don't work here unless you want the tuition reduction, the real public safety is offered by neighbors like Salt Lake City, Salt Lake County and UHP.

job_title: HVAC Controls in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Stable job with great benefits. The employees in the facility division are phenomenal and the knowledge base that they have is awesome.
cons: Staggeringly low pay and inept facility direction. There is a constant restructure culture happening which makes it difficult to perform the job functions in a satisfactory way. While the methodology is not erroneous, the deployment of the changes are conducted in a very unprofessional way. The working class are the last to know of the new positions they are being forced to take.

job_title: Engineering Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great Atmosphere in the university. People around you are really very friendly. Close knit team. They paid me decent salary which was enough to take care of my living expenses.
cons:
The wheather is not that great. It snows heavily and the place is covered with snow for more than half an year.
Sometimes you would have to climb on to a 20ft ladder to finish a few installations and won't suggest someone who has fear of heights to take this up

job_title: Sales Specialist in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The benefits that they provide at the university are great - healthcare, large retirement contribution, and tuition reduction.
cons: The management of the department I'm working in is very poor, and turnover is high. My direct manager is empathetic, and supportive, but ultimately has no power to fix issues in the department. Upper level management is not supportive, and has a hubris that inhibits the department from changing for the better.

review_title: Your employees should matter more than crimson club.
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
Decent work environment 
Easy advancement 
The people you work with can be really great
Ok pay compared to other retail
cons:
The employees are little more than peons
The donors to the school get treated like royalty, which isn't bad but it is when it comes to the store and they would rather keep them happy than the employees

review_title: Good experience as a Grad Student, experience depends on the department
job_title: Teaching Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: With this job you get direct interaction with students and it will definitely let you know if you should go into teaching or even pursue a PhD
cons: The grading workload can be heavy sometimes, especially near exam time. You may be asked to TA for several classes, so that may be overwhelming for those not prepared for that.

job_title: Research Associate in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great quality of life, can have a decent life style with low living expenses, good salary benefits and awesome people.
cons: You really have to push yourself out of your comfort zone if you want to achieve some thing bigger. . People are very relaxed with their current jobs and can work there for years and years with very little amount of salary raise. So, growth is limited

review_title: It is what you make of it, meaning plenty of opportunities for growth, but if you're lazy you won't learn much.
job_title: Laboratory Specialist in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: There are plenty of research opportunities.
cons: Pay is mediocre, and the pension plan doesn't vest for 4 years, and if you don't spend a your career as a state employee, that pension becomes practically worthless since there is no cost-of-living adjustment for the time from when you worked early in your career and when you finally start getting benefits at retirement.

review_title: Still enjoy going to work each day after 25 years..
job_title: Director in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Bright and engaging students that are easy to promote to employers.  Always new and interesting events and promotions on campus.  Multiple supervisors have allowed resources and time to focus on professional development and leadership opportunities.  Competitive benefits
cons: Political decision making process prevalent in higher education - sometimes miss opportunities with time delay.  Salary limitations due to financial model of legislative control over staff and faculty.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The University of Utah offers similar benefits packages to all of it's full-time employees, which was the biggest plus. They have great insurance and are a good place to look for student jobs. I worked in a couple of different departments and they were all flexible with respect to schedule.
