cons: It's a large university, so the time to get HR-related things processed can be longer than expected. Departments vary on how much upward mobility there is.

review_title: It's a good university for research
job_title: Graduate Student in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Salt Lake City is a very beautiful city, and University of Utah is as beautiful as the city. The people here are very nice. The professors in school of computing have very strong backgound. I really learn a lot here.
cons: Utah is somewhat far from the East Coast and California. Hence the career fair is not that good. Not many companies come here.

review_title: I just want my degree, bro
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
1. You get to study at University of Utah and eventually get a degree so that you can move onto something else.

2. You get to be a college student and enjoy all the privileges college life offers

3. Accredited and recognized school

4. Great place to be at if you are in your 20's
cons:
1. Low pay - you are a broke college student all the time

2. Research advisor (boss) sometimes hard to deal with due to incompetence and ignorance

job_title: Medical Translator/Editor in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Top 10 in the nation, very well recognized
cons: You have to fight for a raise because they don't offer a raise, not even a 3-5% yearly raise! If you work on main campus, you have to pay parking as an employee (which isn't cheap), space is very limited and you have to work in a normal single-space office with 4-5 employees. They try to pay as little as possible.

job_title: Molecular Biology Technician-Volunteer Position in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: It's a great place to work and we have very nice people here. It's been a very good experience so far. Currently I am on a part time volunteer position and hope to find a full time paid job as soon as possible.
cons: I haven't encountered any so far (may be because I am not working full time here) and also do not go through the management or any sort of formalities/procedures which may give you a chance to gauge a place/organization.

review_title: The University of Utah can be a great place to work.
job_title: Course Instructor in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Provides good online access to paycheck, benefits, career development and advancement. There are often free courses that can help with your knowledge of software and other career skills. Great benefit packages for salaried employees.
cons: Like most Universities there is always some political or bureaucratic hoops to jump through and that also varies depending on the department that you work for.

job_title: Research Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great coworkers, flexible hours, close to home if you live in Salt Lake. Great opportunities for students if you are interested in anthropology or language. There are unique projects available, which may help the school and the communities you work with.
cons: Unorganized, the boss isn't the best. Can be chaotic. Parking isn't free. Boss to employee communication is horrible. The head of the Department is really what brought this experience down for me.

job_title: Summer Camp Teacher in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Decent pay for teaching kids.  Hours were easy for a simple summer job.  Was able to control my own work environment by determining my own lessons (I was a student teacher).  Free lunch.
cons: Job was only for 6 weeks per summer.  Pay did not increase enough from summer to summer even when the tasks became more demanding.

review_title: Typical Big University - Bureaucracy at its finest but fair and honest.  Solid.
job_title: Software Project Lead in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: State Govt., 14.2% yearly retirement benefit.   457B and 403B.   "Shadow IT" and really nice programming jobs available outside of UIT often provide a very nice work environment.   Semi-autonomous, agile teams in nooks and crannies.
cons: State Govt., lower salary than industry, lots of hoops to get anything done in IT world.  Often slow-paced with too much to do.  UIT is overly, self-regulated.

review_title: Great infrastructure to make each instructor feel valued
job_title: Graduate Student Instructor in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: I worked as a teacher's assistant while in graduate school, which can be an intimidating position, but the U always treated us just like other faculty members.  We had access to all the faculty services they offered, and they also developed workshops just for us, to help us develop our teaching skills.
cons: Work/life balance can be tough to manage, but give it some time.

review_title: My experience was positive, but the on-boarding and scheduling process was a nightmare.
job_title: Intern in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The best thing about working here is the professors you interact with. They are typically understanding and interesting. The ability to network with professors is amazing.
cons: The biggest challenge of working here is working with scheduling and administrative personnel. Many support staff personnel are condescending and incompetent.

review_title: Graduate Student Teacher Assistants Treated MUCH Better Than Undergrad
job_title: Teaching Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: I gained a greater understanding by helping to teach course material to the students.
cons: Graduate students are salaried (guaranteed hours), get ~$18 an hour and full tuition reimbursement for doing the exact same job that I got ~$12 an hour and no tuition assistance for doing.

review_title: Great ! I love the learning experience.
job_title: Teaching Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
It's a great place for academia and research. 
The learning experience is great at the U. 
Salt Lake is a beautiful place.
cons: Not very active industry wise though there is Twitter and Microsoft now :) So if competent enough, location should'nt be a problem.

job_title: Research Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Working at the U provides a lot of educational opportunities.  Not only do you get paid to be there, but you can attend classes at an employees rate.  If you work full time, the benefits are fantastic.  If you're a football fan, they have a great team as well.
cons: You may have to work late nights and long hours as deadlines approach, but that's to be expected from just about any employer that depends on grants for funding.

review_title: Great environment, salaries behind market, great benefits
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: There are jobs for virtually every skill set you can imagine. There are always plenty of new projects coming along so plenty of opportunities to develop your skills.
cons: Salaries are below market in many areas. Funding from the state is always a challenge and can make it a difficult place to work if you're not accustomed to government work.

job_title: Bookstore Employee in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great coworkers and boss, Everyone is really flexible when it comes to setting your schedule because everyone else are also students.
cons: Super boring sometimes and time passes so slowly, not much to do when it's not football season, really low pay.

job_title: Office Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: This position offers great networking, you meet faculty, staff, alumni, current student, and prospective students. You are also involved with many events outside of the university.
cons: This job is very repetitive, your typical desk job. For the most part you are doing the same things everyday which include data entry, printing documents and putting thing away for others.

review_title: Most Departments Fine Except for School of Dentistry
job_title: Lab Technician in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The health benefits at the University of Utah seem to be very good.  The Cobra equivalent costs $1,500/month for a 3 person family.
cons: Like I said in my title, the University of Utah is a fairly good place to work, but the School of Dentistry is a terrible work environment.  A lot of the dental assistants there LOVE gossiping, back-stabbing, demeaning other co-workers, students, and staff, and they freely commit HIPAA violations to satisfy their curiosity.  It was a very unprofessional work environment and very toxic, to say the least.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great benefits, vacation, and sick time.  Great Core facilities to help out with your research projects/goals.  A few hidden gems in the faculty.
cons: Salary is quite low but the norm in Utah.  Salary increases and promotions are unheard of.  Upper management are clueless or turn their heads away toward wasteful scientific research projects.

job_title: Administrative Officer in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The benefits are killer. You can work in any subject you are interested in. You learn a lot about what is happening in current research.
cons:
It is a huge University with lots of road blocks to get your job completed, simple tasks can sometimes take too long. 

It is hard to get promoted in the same department. Your best option is to move somewhere else on campus. 

Staff is not always treated with respect by faculty.

review_title: Great place to work while attending school.
job_title: Parking Enforcement Officer in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The University of Utah is a great place to work while attending school. They offered good benefits, including tuition reduction and okay pay.
cons: There were minimal advancement opportunities. There as a high turn-over rate as we dealt with people who were upset about parking tickets.

review_title: Great employer and fantastic way to finance my education
job_title: Graduate Student Instructor in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Tuition benefit, flexible hours, competitive pay versus other part-time opportunities, and great experience for your resume are a just a few reasons working as a graduate instructor is the perfect opportunity for anyone who can get it.
cons: Often the work can be stressful, especially when dealing with upset or struggling students. I occasionally have to work a few more than 20 hours in the week to make sure everything gets done.

job_title: in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: It really depends on your boss. If you have a good boss, it is a great place to work. If you have a lousy boss, it is horrible.
cons: Anyone, including fellow employees can look up your pay on the internet. I didn't find any room for advancement. Management seems entrenched.

review_title: Great benefits and diversity in Salt Lake City
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: I work in Health Science, which is very different from main campus. The pros are easy: outstanding benefits package, diversity of staff (very open and accepting generally), the chance to work with some incredibly smart people, opportunities to learn and grow.
cons: Incredibly political, bureaucratic and slow to adapt. Utah itself is simultaneously a pro and a con. As in many good organizations, it is hard to move up because people don't leave.

job_title: Information Technology Specialist in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Get to work on interesting projects. Flexible schedule. Tuition benefits for post secondary education.
cons: Low pay. Raises are very hard to secure. Professors are paid a great deal of money when admin/staff are not. It is completely out of balance. Leaving staff feeling like they are undervalued.

review_title: Great place to work during school
job_title: Work Study Student in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The school takes great care to ensure that work study has plenty of time and balance for school.  It's also a great place to work for in general, with a great culture of dedicated people.
cons: The only con I can really think of is that as a part time worker, you don't get all the general benefits that full time does, such as the ability to use payroll deduction at the computer store.

job_title: Research Associate in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
Great retirement
Great benefits
Employer respects individual thinking. I work in research and my opinion is valued. I feel like I am making a contribution.
cons: We are slow to move on new technology. It is sometimes difficult to deal with the red tape. The pay may be lower than industry.

job_title: Office Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Very flexible with school. It's great to have classes and work within a block of each other. The management and coworkers are a great crew.
cons: I could use some more hours, but that would also conflict with school. I wish we didn't have to pay so much for parking.

job_title: Security Guard in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Good benefits if you use only U of U doctors and facilities.
cons: I worked very hard , studied my job at home. Made one mistake which I immediately rectified and was fired without being able to be heard. I my job well and always helped out others or locked additional areas with a smile on my face. For some reason the employees hated me and I was fired. I couldn't believe it because I'd never had words with anybody.

review_title: Its all about how you say it
job_title: Market Research Analyst in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The technology managers are great to work with, are well connected, and are very supportive. This is a great chance to get to know how to evaluate a potential market as well as what to consider before starting a business.
cons: The analyst managers don't really care what is said only that it is said with absolute confidence. Don't believe anything they say, no matter how much they promise that it is true.

job_title: Orientation Leader in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The University of Utah is a well respected and well run institution of higher learning. During my time here as a student employee, I was impressed with the institutional organization hierarchy.
cons: Tends to pay on the lower end of the spectrum. We also worked very, very long shifts without many breaks during the summer due to a huge influx of new students needing to go through orientation.

job_title: Graduate Instructor in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Tuition reimbursement, excellent support, good students.  I like that literature students are able to teach 2600 and some other literature classes.
cons: High teaching load for grad students in the English Ph.D. program. It would be nice if we only taught 2 courses per year, but 3 courses per year is not unreasonable.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Classes were non-challenging, although this could be considered a negative for most people.
cons: Over-worked as a graduate student, putting in well over the maximum of 20 hours per week. Entire school is an organizational nightmare and prepare to be indoctrinated into a particular set of political beliefs or be socially ostracised.

review_title: The research opportunity was once in a lifetime.
job_title: in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: I was able to be actively involved and contribute to research that has helped countless peoples lives all over the globe.
cons: The pay was not very good.  I did not have my own personal working space.  I was not taken seriously for graduate school.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The University of Utah is a good location for interdisciplinary research. There are many opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students alike and it seems each year more research funding is being awarded to projects on campus. Open door policies are common cross talk is strongly encouraged.
cons: Salt Lake is not the largest metropolitan area so the opportunity to interact with other Universities is not as easy as is in other places in the country.

job_title: Senior Web Developer in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: My schedule is flexible, my salary is competitive, and my benefits are great.  My supervisor is very hands-off and leads by personality, not by micromanaging my projects.  I am recognized for good work and received a significant promotion after 3 years of working here.
cons: The academic year dictates my work load, so a few months of the year are incredibly hectic.

job_title: Program Manager in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Benefit package is amazing, health care is affordable, they contribute to retirement, and PTO is great.
cons: Management is short-sighted and paranoid.  I've seen many lower pay-grade positions 'thrown under the bus' in order for the supervisor to look good and keep there job.  HR seems to go with the higher-ranking side.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
The pay is generous. The tuition fees for the school gets waived off, which is the best part. But this depends on your School. 
Being a Graduate Teaching assistant, you get to interact with a lot of people.
It is also a good way to get to know the faculty
cons: Depending on the course you are assisting, it can be sometimes demanding and you may have to spend more than the expected hours.

review_title: Great for student positions with opportunities for future advancement.
job_title: in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: If you are a student here then it would be definitely beneficial to work at school in order to network with other students, professors, and faculty.
cons: The wage is OK. You are expected to work over hours because positions can be competitive. Also depending on the position (if you are working as a teaching assistant, etc.), it could affect school schedule in a negative way.

review_title: Great place to learn and work at the same time
job_title: Computer Operator in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great schedule options to work with class schedule. Duties are not too difficult. Supervisors and managers are willing to help and teach. You have to sometimes be an acting-librarian, helping patrons find books, research articles, etc.
cons: Sometimes it gets a little monotonous. And there's a steep learning curve for some things you have to help with.

review_title: Not a Pleasant Place To Work-Hostile Work Environment
job_title: Out Patient Medical Biller in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
Pay is Fair
Lay Off's are rare
cons:
Infrequent contact with managment
management does not consider feedback from employees
gossiping and favoritism
inexperienced and unprofessional management=unhappy employees

job_title: Manager in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Lots of opportunity if you choose to take it up. Filled with intellectual stimulation, great people, bright minds and good causes.
cons: Lots of bureaucracy if you choose to let it slow you down. Some folks think their job is to play politics and game the system. Can be exhausting.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Good pay and beautiful campus. Engineering is good and has many start-ups from Alumni. Professors are research competent.
cons: Teaching is just OK. Looks like professors are not interested in teaching courses.

job_title: Research Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
The faculty in Mechanical Engineering is very good
The proximity to the outdoors is incredible.  Most grad students ski, climb, bike, camp, etc. 
The university is growing rapidly
cons:
The school is still not top-tier, which puts graduates at a disadvantage for some positions
Though still relatively cheap, Salt Lake rent is on the rise making it more difficult to survive off of typical graduate salaries.

review_title: Best benefits in the Salt Lake Valley
job_title: Executive Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
- hard working faculty and staff
 - remote work from home is a real perk
 - plenty of opportunities for career development
 - interesting and varied work assignments
 - HR works for both you and the institution
cons: No known negative concerns at the University of Utah.

job_title: Manager in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great benefits, community atmosphere, great people
cons: Low pay, one person works hard while another does not and yet they make the same wage; there is not great equality at the U, all departments are so different in how they work with other departments; one is quick to respond and another does not respond. I think all departments should be equally important and one department is not better than the other.

job_title: Research Study Coordinator in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great learning-centered and collaborative environment, great benefits, many in-house opportunities for job growth; half-price tuition for self and family, mature co-workers; beautiful campus
cons: Salary not as competitive as private industry for some occupations; limited parking; substantial raises can be hard to come by unless you switch positions in some areas, but you don't have to leave the company to do so

job_title: Administrative Officer in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The benefits are amazing and there is lots of opportunity to grow and move into different departments. Once you know the systems it’s very easy to transition into another area.
cons: It is hard to get a raise or promotion unless you leave your department. Staff are not the priority and can be treated poorly by faculty. You can luck out and have a great supervisor but in my experience it was rare.

review_title: It is a great university. It provides its students what they need and give guidance for their career.
job_title: Research Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great location. Salt lake city is a beautiful place to work. You can enjoy the snow, sunshine and nice people. The University is strong in a lot of fields and provide a lot of opportunities. So you can learn knowledge and prepare yourself for a better tomorrow.
cons: The whether is dry. So be prepared.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: there is a lot of flexibility in the schedule and many perks associated with the University including free use of public transit
cons: the position is very self-directed and depending on work style, this can lead to low productivity.   parking can be very difficult

job_title: Accounting Clerk in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: It's a really nice working environment and friendly co-workers. If you are a student employee at the Bookstore, you can get benefit on renting textbooks!
cons: They don't pay much on student part-timer. Maybe it's just me, they required me to work more hours, but I have school work and the schedule didn't match their requirement. Therefore, I was only doing paper work for more than 10 months.

review_title: Best place to work while in college
job_title: Marketing Intern in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: As a student, any on campus job prioritizes schooling over job. Being able to take off work during finals week is wonderful. Pay is fair.
cons: Administration is unorganized no matter where you work on campus. Overall, it is good to work on campus and I would highly recommend it

job_title: Research Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great Research Opportunities in an up and coming university. The areas of research are limitless with great cross-disciplinary work happening in each department.
cons: As an RA expect to put in more hours than you can. As with all RA positions, time is money for getting grants renewed.

job_title: Staff Specialist in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Office is really laid back, everyone is nice and friendly. They normally don't  fire anyone, don't have to worry about job security. Never late on paycheck.
cons:
The wage is relatively low compared to similar jobs at corporate employers, maybe because University's funding is quite limited. 
A lot of people working here would eventually choose to retire here, so promotion opportunities are limited.

job_title: Collection Services Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great for students, easy scheduling, doesn't conflict with classes, only work on weekdays, always off on holidays
cons: You can only work there under student status for 6 months after you graduate and then you have to find a new job. Not many promotions, no way to move up or really get a raise.

job_title: Apartment Prep Maintenance Worker in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: good work hour people are friendly.
cons: unorganized place to work and work thier for 3 and half week and not gotten payed yet and have what an extra two weeks till I get payed. I am getting my tool;s and going home tomorrow. I guess that is why a lot of people have quite.

review_title: Academic life and research in the University of Utah
job_title: Research Assistant Professor in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Collaborative culture; modern campus; beautiful surroundings. Well connected to Salt Lake City.
cons: Lack of opportunities for progress within the institution; no major state competitors leave the U. of Utah as the only option, which is a downside for multiple reasons.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The benefits are great.  The diversity of the work population is great.  I loved working at the U.
cons: The pay is low in a lot of the on campus jobs.  It is better in the Health Sciences area.

job_title: Phonathon Caller in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great hours with a school schedule; good pay for a college student; work with other kids in similar life situations; great experience initiating and maintaining conversations; opportunities for continuous raises over time
cons: Challenging experience if you dislike asking people for money

review_title: Looking to climb the career ladder?  Look elsewhere
job_title: Coordinator in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great benefits, good work/life balance, cool environment, flexible schedule, management is typically supportive of employees continuing their education or obtaining advanced degrees.
cons: Little opportunity for advancement, compensation is driven more by time with the organization than by skill or contributions.  Some departments pay better than others, but in general salary will be less than a similar position in the private sector.

job_title: in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
great skiing and hiking (and anything else outdoors)
relaxed atmosphere
easy place to live: cheap housing, easy commuting
international airport is 25 minutes away
good benefits
pleasant place to work
cons:
not much opportunity for advancement 
small town feel (which can be nice) but  is also lacking cultural diversity 
pay is not great but the university offers good benefits 
recruiting and retaining good scientists seems to be difficult

job_title: Project Coordinator in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: University of Utah continuing education department- and specifically the Professional Education and Technology Education departments- are psychologically safe, engaged places to work. We are constantly coming up with new ideas and implementing changes.
cons: It's an academic atmosphere so sometimes the focus is much more on tradition than innovation, although changes are usually welcomed. Pay can't be too fabulous either because it is a nonprofit environment.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: It is a really nice jobs not a lot of and it great for students
cons: Dull the job load is not that exciting, its a routine job were nothing fun really goes around.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
1. Benefits
2. Location
3. skiing
4. NA
5. NA
cons:
1.  Poor compensation
2.  Relationship between a postdoctoral fellow and mentor not great at least based on my personal experience.  They treat you as slaves and expect you to put up with all their crap and internal politics.  The senior advisors / asian professors are the worst.  Learn more about the group before joining.  Communication was non-existant.

job_title: Office Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Working for the University of Utah is greet. My title may not be impressive but I always felt part of the team and my work is always rewarded. I work while going to school and my bosses and other coworkers around me are consistantly helping me further myself in order to get a great job when I graduate
cons: Some times of the year are slower.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: This place a good work environment. It is very supportive for research. I was able to set my own schedule, which was very nice.
cons: I have been here for six years and have not been paid very well. The pay is competitive, but not easy to live off of. It's difficult to graduate and move on if everything doesn't go exactly as needed.

job_title: Adjunct Teacher in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great pay and hours, freedom to design courses.
cons: Typical school politics, Occasional other faculty will sit in on a class then I will find out a few months later that they were there to lift a section of your designed curriculum to use in their classes. I have had students come into my classes having done my exact assignments to the letter that I had created.

job_title: Graduate Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great environment, flexible hours , great and smart people to work with. Very blessed to have this opportunity because you can meet tons of different people
cons: Sometimes you are tied to the monotony of it. Sometimes it's frustrating because what you are asked for it's fairly simple.

job_title: Adjunct Assistant Professor in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The University of Utah is Utah's flagship public university, and it shows. This is a top-notch public institution with a broad diversity of programs and lots of resources.
cons: Teaching part-time as an adjunct professor doesn't pay very well, but if you get a full-time, salaried position, the benefits are great.

job_title: Student Researcher in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Competitive pay, interesting work, flexible schedule. I have been extremely happy working at the University of Utah.
cons: As a student wanting to go into industry, some employers prefer to see previous experience at companies versus research.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: I enjoy being part of an institution of higher education that offers excellent academic opportunities, museums, gardens, medical centers, etc.
cons: Salary isn't competitive. In my particular workplace, employee morale has been low due to ineffective leadership that doesn't value its human resources.

review_title: It was a great job but the job was a seasonal job
job_title: Southern Belle Farms in McDonough, GA
pros: After your first season of working there, your paycheck is boosted. Only work on the weekends..have 12hr and 6hr shifts only
cons: It's a seasonal job so it doesn't last very long. Through dome harsh conditions, you still have to work

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Flexible Schedule. Many options for hours of work. Professional work environment, with great co workers and good students. A Teaching Assistant is a great role for students, especially if you're a people person or good with people in general.
cons: Procrastinating students will almost always need a ton of attention at the end of the semester. This is a bother because you are really busy yourself.

review_title: I'm pursuing my PhD at the University of Utah Chemical Engineering Department. I'm a graduate research assistant.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: A supportive, great learning environment to do research.
cons: You have to work late hours (but this is something valid for all graduate degrees in engineering), and due to the nature of funding you may end up switching projects if you are under tuition benefit at some point during your research.

job_title: Instructional Designer in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Creative staff and student employees made coming to work interesting. We were given great opportunities to solve problems and invent new solutions as we created new programs.
cons: Faculty are often divas and can sometimes demand more than they have a right to. Some staff have fallen into the trap of thinking that faculty are actually better than other people, not just different.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The best part of this job was the flexible hour option. Co workers were very helpful and very understanding
cons: Many times the requirements of the projects changed after couple of sprints . This used to cause sometimes a lot of design modification .

review_title: A good transition job from grad school, but not a place to stay forever
job_title: Assistant Coach in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
Good work/life balance
Great outdoors
Flexible work schedule
Great benefits etc
Fun co-workers
PAC-12 affiliation makes it a growing institution
cons:
No feedback
No recognition for a job well done
Low salary
University-wide budget cuts
No real opportunities for advancement in department

job_title: Lab Technician in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Good Benefits, paid vacations, dental, vision, paid holidays, excellent faculty and staff enjoyed the work, possibility to advance with more education, half price tuition for self/spouse/children.  Good values, free public transit pass, and nice activities.
cons: Low cost of Living in Salt Lake City = Low pay, hard to go back to school to advance while working 40-hours per week.

job_title: Postdoctoral in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: I worked in the math department for almost a year. There are several active groups in many areas of research including applied math, algebraic geometry, probability and math biology.
cons: The postdoc salary at the university of Utah is higher than many other places. There are many conferences, and and research activities taking place all the time

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Very supportive and collaborative environment to do biomedical research. Highly competitive. Mentors support professional development even if it takes up some of the time that could be spent at the bench.
cons: Whether you have a great experience or not depends on exactly who you do your postdoc with. As everywhere, some mentors are great, others not so great. Pick carefully.

job_title: RN, Bsn in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great benefits, specifically health insurance if you have a family.  Care about employees.  Great learning environment. They now have levels for nurses to encourage BSN and other specialty certification (CCNE, CNOR)
cons: You have to pay for parking.

job_title: Research Associate in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Faculty are generally easy to work with and collaborate well.  Exciting research areas and projects.  Funding is typically easily available for projects.
cons: Access to particular specialized equipment seems to be somewhat limited.

review_title: Politics about ruin a fantastic job
job_title: Project Manager II in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
Flexible hours
Room for growth (if you are "in" with the right people)
Great benefits
cons:
Administration in my department is terrible
Politics-Politics-Politics
They forget they are dealing with real people and not just names

review_title: Staff nurse on various Oncology units
job_title: Oncology Staff Nurse in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The oncology units really pamper their nurses.  Notes of encouragement, tokens of appreciation, and an open door policy to meet with managers.
cons: There are the usual annoying office politics--just stay out them as much as possible.  If it's a serious issue, the management will step in and facilitate a solution rather than ignoring it.

review_title: Great place for research and education
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Nice people, safe and quite place. High-quality of research, very good support from the Univeristy.beatiful campus.
cons: less variaty, no too much fun activity unless you like ski in the winter, too dry for me, sometimes boring.

review_title: Good place to work, but you are expendable
job_title: Customer Service
pros: Good benefits. Pays well for entry level jobs.
cons: If you are going for an entry level job, make sure you are getting clearly defined expectations from your supervisor so that you don't do something innocuous that they'll fire you over if the department decides one day on a whim that it is overstaffed.

review_title: Chemistry Department - World Class Research, Third Rate Safety and Graduate program
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Outstanding Facilities, well known and respected PIs, decent stipend
cons:
Terrible work politics among faculty
Faculty care more about their own career advancement than graduate student progress and success
Safety is nowhere near a top priority
Accidents and misconduct are ignored rather than remedying underlying issues, no accountability for those responsible

review_title: Great benefits, very little annual raises
job_title: Nursing Supervisor in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The benefits can’t be matched! I had a 1 day ICU admission that I paid $0 for. Retirement package is excellent.
cons: The annual raises have been less than the cost of living and are not merit based. It’s an across the board raise for everyone. If you work harder than your coworkers, you are not rewarded for it.

job_title: Program Manager in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Excellent benefits, emphasis on education, gorgeous campus. For Utah, it's a really diverse place.
cons: Not a lot of room for advancement, leading people aren't always paid for what they're worth.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Research top tier university. Good faculty that can get you awesome positions if you are their research students.
cons: As with any public university, the area surrounding the university is not as technology aware as say the bigger cities. It has a good start up culture around.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The benefits package is very good, however, if you want to go to a doctor outside of the U of Utah you will pay higher co pays. Overall the research environment is good here.
cons: There is little chance for upward mobility at the university as a postdoctoral fellow, but this might be the case for academia, in general. Parking is terrible.

job_title: Gameplay Programmer in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: You can  make the project yours and really help in the overall design. The bosses and the director are great people and will definitely help with your overall growth. There is culture building every week or every other week where you do fun activities for the first 30 mins of the Friday.
cons: Nothing I can think of.

job_title: Computer Technician in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Job security, generally friendly staff and faculty.
cons: Lots of turf, silos and other politics at play.  Particularly true in the IT realm.  Too many cooks in the kitchen and not enough brains upstairs.

review_title: An amazing mix of talent from across the academic spectrum.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Cutting edge research, cross-disciplinary faculty, with expertise in many areas of computing. Weekly colloquia, invited speakers and seminars. Free sodas, free coffie, ping pong, foosball. Great environment to work in. Located near by some of the best wilderness in the US. Cost of living is cheap.
cons: Isolated from other major cities.

review_title: Continuing Education at the U of U
job_title: Administrative Program Coordinator in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
50% tuition discount is great! 
The health insurance is good, and the deductibles are low. All staff also get a free transit pass for bus and light rail travel.
cons: Employees have to pay for a parking pass, which can be deducted from your pay. The salaries are not as high as they could be elsewhere.

job_title: Graduate Student in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great variety of professors to work with.
cons:
Pay discrepancy between graduate students within the same department as much as 20%.
Not much departmental support for labs that don't have much money.
Same problem as every other graduate program - over worked, under paid, no retirement. I will be well into my 30's by the time I can start really saving money for retirement.

job_title: Nurse in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Good benefits and decent pay.
cons: Horrible work environment - management does nothing to minimize bullying and crudeness around the workplace. I've found this to be true in multiple departments (from first and second hand experience). Parking is awful and you have to pay for it yourself. The benefits do not outweigh the toxicity.

review_title: Great way to get your education paid for
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: I worked as a graduate research assistant in one of the University labs. The pay was great for being part-time. In addition, healthcare was paid for. Most of the work I performed was relevant to the degree I was seeking.
cons: Some of the work performed was not very relevant to degree I was seeking.

review_title: A typical research assistant graduate student experience
job_title: Research Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The city is spectaticular. It only lacks a beach. The professors are knowlagable about their specialties. Intellegent coworkers. Fairly easy to get funding.
cons: Research assistant pay, inversions in the wintertime. Pay for grad students is 20K at most.  Sometimes getting stuck on projects that do not help graduation and getting on to a carrier.

review_title: Love the work environment. Really sad to leave the position.

job_title: Senior Web Developer in Tooele, UT

job_title: Speech Language Pathologist in Salt Lake City, UT

job_title: Administrative Officer in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
Benefits (PTO and HOL) are great
Good health and dental Insurance plans

Untrained Management 
Pay for Parking is Expensive

review_title: An excellent place to do biomedical research.

review_title: Good place to work and a laid back environment

review_title: U of U is on the move!

review_title: Gauss is the place to be.

review_title: Great for students, but not for a career
job_title: Collection Services Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT

job_title: Research Associate in Salt Lake City, UT

job_title: Assistant Director in Salt Lake City, UT

pros: Benefits. As much overtime as you want.
cons: Micro management on steroids. Angry Public Safety Administration abuses, yells at and threatens department employees. Everyone gets "write-ups" (except a couple of special people who cannot do anything wrong) Terrible employee relations and they don't care. They can't even hire as fast as people quit and they still don't care.

job_title: Visiting Scientist in Salt Lake City, UT

job_title: Accounting Specialist in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great benefits! Cheap insurance that's actually good, free public transportation, discounted tuition, lots of pto, and sometimes you get free tickets to sporting events and other activities.

job_title: Lab Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT

cons: If you aren't a student or full-time, you don't get the pros of the job. Might as well work anywhere else where there are better opportunities to move up in your job.

review_title: Great fun, really flexible with your school schedule

review_title: Good student job, salary plus tuition benefit and subsidized U of U health insurance make it really worthwhile.

review_title: Love the staff here and the pay is very fair.

review_title: Great place to work, and a great place to build professional relationships

review_title: Nice working environment with smiling faces around
